thread.title: Brave brothers save 10ft hammerhead shark stranded on Florida beach by removing large fishing hooks from its mouth and dragging it back to sea
thread.title_full: Brave brothers save 10ft hammerhead shark stranded on Florida beach by removing large fishing hooks from its mouth and dragging it back to sea | Daily Mail Online

author: Jake Polden For Mailonline
title: Brave brothers save 10ft hammerhead shark stranded on Florida beach by removing large fishing hooks from its mouth and dragging it back to sea
text:
7 shares 7
View
comments
This is the heartwarming moment a pair of brothers removed large fishing hooks from an injured hammerhead shark and dragged it back to sea.
The big fish was spotted near a beach in Destin, Florida, with the hooks attached to its mouth and steel fishing line tangled in and around its head.
Writing on YouTube, alongside the video, one of the men involved said: ‘My brother, once realising it [the shark] was injured, swam out to bring it to shore away from people still in the water.
Brothers save hammerhead shark from line caught in mouth The big fish was spotted near a beach in Destin, Florida with steel fishing line tangled in and around its head
The brothers realised the shark was injured and swam out to it to so that they could bring it to shore, away from other people in the water
‘I filmed this heroic display as he dragged the injured 10 foot hammerhead to shore.
‘The shark was pulled to shore and we realised it had several deep sea fishing hooks in its mouth as well as steel fishing line tangled in and around its head.
 Next 'They’re foreign tourists. You’re blatantly ripping them... Dramatic footage captures leopard growling inside a school... Is this a cruel act? Cat owners slammed over 'appalling'... How did he do that? Magician stuns crowd by revealing... ‘My brother, along with help from bystanders, worked to get the hooks out and save the dying shark.
‘My brother was able to pull the shark into deeper water until it was able to swim away safely in an attempt to avoid further injuring itself or the public.’
The brothers realised the shark had several deep sea fishing hooks in its mouth and they set about removing them
In the video, the man struggled to remove the hook and required help from other people to keep the shark still
In the video, the man can be seen struggling to remove the hooks before a number of other people help by holding onto the shark in a bid to keep it still.
Other people can be seen chucking water onto the fish throughout the process and before long the hooks are removed to the sound of cheering from the crowd.
The shark appears to be disorientated however, and after swimming out to sea returns to the shoreline.
The group managed to remove the hooks from the big fish and people cheered as it swam back out to sea
This prompts one of the two brothers to grab hold of the shark and rather bravely drag it to deep water.
There are 10 known species of hammerhead shark, but only the scalloped, great, and smooth are known to be dangerous to humans.
There have been 33 recorded attacks as of 2013 but no fatalities.
